intro: Lappa janczewskii, commonly known as the narrowleaf hogweed, is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its umbellate inflorescence and aromatic foliage. It is native to Central Asia and is known for its tall, slender stems that can reach up to two meters in height. The plant features large, deeply lobed leaves that are typically bluish-green in color. Its flowers are small and white, arranged in compound umbels, and it produces small, dry fruits known as schizocarps. Lappa janczewskii is often found in moist, open habitats such as meadows and riverbanks.
